It's about context. In a real food (plant/animal - such that is not produced in a factory, food that once had a life on its own) - chemicals that make it are result of complex interactions between the plant/animal and its environment during its lifespan. If the soil was say mineral depleted, so will be the plants that grew on it and animals that ate those plants. Man made foods on the other hand are, biologically speaking - totally random. Most of them are just made to taste good. Chemicals that are added are mostly to enhance taste/texture (increasing the pleasure of eating it, therefore making it more addictive), or to prolong shelf life (making the product more marketable).

The problem is context.

There is a reason for each and every nutrient in each and every real food. That is - a biological reason. We don't know most of the cause/effect relationships here, but if a chemical is present in a plant/animal it has a very specific role in defining that plant for what it is. We may not know that role for each chemical, but we need to start appreciating the complexity of nature more. (both when we eat, and when we grow our foods)

So by eating real foods, we do not only eat the chemicals these foods contain - we actually eat those foods, with their colour, taste, texture, that each and every one of those chemicals contribute to uniquely. And it's the whole food that produces a reaction of our bodies. A very specific one at that. 

It's not that man made foods are toxic themselves, it is a lack of context that confuses delicate systems inside a human body that is. And by toxic i do not refer to a specific chemical, since, a dose is a poison - i refer to "incompleteness" of the information received by a living organism by eating "incomplete" foods. Saying that there are less chemicals in a candy vs. a banana is trivial. Actually it would be so crazy weird if it was not the case.

Yes everything is made of "chemicals", but that doesn't mean all chemicals are to be treated the same. The reason we call them chemicals is because they usually come from a chemistry lab or a chemical processing facility. When laymen, like me, say "chemicals" it's usually intended to imply "industrial chemicals", it's not intended to evoke romanticized notions of the periodic table of elements, and all types of chemical compounds, both natural and synthetic. 

The long term effects of industrial chemicals on things like the endocrine system, and other non-symptomatic effects on the body are extremely difficult determine. Our digestive system is made to process food when it is available in certain natural packaging format i.e. apple, banana, orange etc. All food we consume is processed to some extent, from peeling a banana, to kneading dough, to cooking it. However, there is a line in the sand, and when you start using industrial chemical processes to change the properties of the food, it does not seem unreasonable to allow people to have the freedom to make a choice.This looks more like a marketing video for chemical companies than anything else. 

These days people are making choices based on the past actions of chemical companies. The "scientists" who claim that chemical x is safe have been proven wrong so many times in the past that people are getting sick of hearing the same story again and again. If they want to be successful, then how about success through actual down-to-earth good science, and not just marketing, and political swindling to avoid spending money on food safety research.

This is how people get confused..Fruits and vegetables have a long historical back drop of trial and error and safety. This is why we know not to eat poisonous mushrooms. The true argument is that man made chemicals are relatively new on the scene and don't have the historical backing like most foods do. Although foods have been manipulated by man to produce things like seedless watermelon typically that manipulation doesn't lead to a poison. Occasionally it does. Moral of the story for me? Stick with whole foods that history has already revealed to us as safe. Furthermore, the essential nutrients necessary for life and survival are found in whole foods. Sure we can make it in a lab with the help of other essential things ie, glucose manipulated to make vitamin c. But it still remains that these essential substances originated and started in whole foods. blah blah blah..I could go on and on.

P.S - The reaction to historically backed substances for ingestion also allow for a broader predictability in how are liver and body will break the substances down. In other words, for the majority of the population, eating a banana will not result in the creation of a new substance by the liver that can cause harm or death. How do we know this? Well when is the last time you watched the news etc and people became sick or died from eating a banana? However, think back of how many times you have watched recalls on novel drugs during a television commercial. Some of you here can attests to getting headaches from consuming aspartame or sucralose. Guess what? It is still controversial although you know you don't feel right. But don't worry in 10 years time researchers will likely come out and agree that what you are experiencing is not in your head.
The problem is we become experiments for these new substances.

As far as dose goes.. well...once again humans have a rough idea due to inherent mechanisms that let them know they don't need anymore of a substance the body recognizes as essential such as water. However, some are arguing that chemicals and other things (like stress) may be helping to disrupt this natural mechanism that let's you know you have, for instance, had enough sugar or fat dose. Yes almost too much of anything can kill you. When it comes to essential nutrients, too little of something can kill you also.

 Please feel free to eat your experimental stuff and I'll stick with what works regardless of how long or complicated the sound of the substance found in my fruit is.

While an entry level chemistry class (and I'm not talking college) will educate you that everything is made of chemicals, those chemicals do not exist in a vacuum.  As the video itself suggests, the ratios are quite important.  The manner and sequence in which they come together can also be extremely relevant, as evidenced by anyone who has ever tried to bake a cake or raise a loaf of bread.  More importantly, this video has the audacity to begin to equate artificial (and even natural) selection with GMOs.  What I can't imagine they're too dense to miss is that these selection types are things that COULD happen in nature.  With artificial selection, man accelerates the process.  What you will never see in nature is a mosquito mating with an apple.  Sorry, folks, not physically possible- no matter how sexy the apple is, that pair will NEVER produce offspring.  And these are the kinds of pairings they successfully produce in the lab, but they do with with no empirical evidence of the effects on people, other animals, the environment, etc. ad nauseum.  Specifically studies of a long-term nature.  We ARE the study.  And more legislation is being written every day so that we have no say in that.  In this "free market", they are paying lobbyists so that consumers don't get to decide who they'll support.  I don't care what your stance is on GMOs, and frankly I'm not claiming a blanket objection to them.  But I do object strenuously to their methodology.  And so should you.

I can't believe so few people in the comments section understand the difference between GMO and artificial selection. They are not the same! Read:

A GMO (Genetically Modified Organism) is a laboratory process of taking genes from one species and inserting them into another in an attempt to obtain a desired trait or characteristic.

Artificial selection is the intentional breeding of plants or animals. It means the same thing as selective breeding. Selective breeding is a technique used when breeding domesticated animals, such as dogs, pigeons or cattle. Some of these animals will have traits that a breeder will want to preserve.

This seems needlessly pedantic and hyperbolic.  I think, on some level, everyone knows everything is made-up of chemicals and that natural fruits and vegetables are loaded with things we "cannot pronounce."  The problem comes with some manufactured foods where they use numerous chemicals as preservatives, flavor enhancers, or to replace a natural source. (Using HFC rather than sugar, for example.) Keep in mind on of these "chemicals" is hydrogenated oil, commonly known as a "trans fat" which is scientifically proven to be treated differently by the body than unsaturated fats.  One your body can process, store and dispense of easily, the other is too much for your body to deal with so it just stores it and deals with it when it really has to.

Now, I don't buy into the whole thing where they say to only buy things if you can pronounce the ingredients in it because I realize those preservatives and such are needed to give the food a meaningful shelf life and the quantities in it aren't enough to be harmful (supposedly.) But I don't think it's terrible either if people avoid such foods and go with foods that have no, or more natural, preservatives.

So, I think there's a huge difference between eating an apple (which, OMG, has an un-noteworthy amount of cyanide in it!  That can kill you! If you eat like a truck-load full of apples, or seeds from a literal truck-load full of apples, inside of a few minutes and you were able to crush the seeds up thoroughly with your teeth because that's the only way to release the poison) and eating the store-brand box of Fruit Loops filled with HFC and preservatives because, hey, they both contain "just chemicals." 

One's a collection of chemicals that are good for you that provide nutritious value to your body and was made by nature, the other is manufactured substance made by a company wanting to save money on manufacturing to maximize profits, so buy a cheap knock-off of sugar, stuff it with air and stick some preservatives in it.

Is the latter bad for you?  Probably not strictly, but the apple is far better for you by any metric.

Seriously -- this is exactly the problem when people subscribe to the naturalistic fallacy.

ASAP Science continues to wreak "semantic havoc" when talking about food. They often speak of "natural," "GMO," etc. without accurately defining what they mean.

Cross breeding the seeds of various types of tomatoes is one thing, whereas GMO tomatoes that are a result of splicing fish genes with tomato genes carries with it a very different meaning and implications.
OR
Natural chemicals that make up a banana carry a different meaning than when those same chemicals are used to create a candy that perhaps contains said chemicals but in different amounts than contained in the banana and in combination with other chemicals that in turn can indeed render them harmful or in the very least unhealthy.

I'm not saying "natural", "GMO's," etc. are good or bad, I'm just saying that if you're making a claim using words with multiple meanings you need to accurately describe which meaning you are basing your claims on.
